Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization is addressed in Section 1. Taiwan's substantial achievements in health include having one of the highest life expectancy levels in Asia, with a population greater than three-quarters of the member states in the World Health Organization. Taiwan has high life expectancy levels in Asia, low maternal and infant mortality rates, eradicated infectious diseases like cholera and smallpox, and collaborates closely with the US CDC on public health issues. Taiwan also provides hepatitis B vaccinations to children and offers financial and technical assistance for international health activities supported by the WHO. In response to a 2001 earthquake in El Salvador, Taiwan sent 2 rescue teams. The Taiwanese Government sent 2 rescue teams with 90 specialists to assist in relief efforts in El Salvador. Additionally, the United States expressed support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations, including the World Health Assembly. Taiwan seeks meaningful participation in the WHO, supported by the US for contribution despite membership limitations. Secretary Thompson emphasized America's efforts for global health at the World Medical Association. Taiwan supports efforts for global health, including seeking observership status at the World Health Assembly. The government donated $1,000,000 to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria in 2002. Taiwan faced challenges with SARS and bird flu outbreaks in 2003. Avian influenza, or bird flu, has reemerged in Asia, with strains reported in multiple countries. The importance of global health organizations like the WHO is emphasized as infectious diseases spread rapidly due to globalization. The Secretary of Health and Human Services recognized the need for effective public health worldwide during the 2003 World Health Assembly meeting. The Secretary of State is authorized to take action. The Secretary of State is authorized to endorse and obtain observer status for Taiwan at the World Health Assembly in Geneva, Switzerland. A report must be submitted to Congress detailing the plan annually.
